title: Is Tyrese Haliburton the best passer in the NBA?
text:
The NBA sparks major debates on who is the best player, scorer, defender, rebounder, passer, and more. This season, Tyrese Haliburton is the best and most efficient passer in the NBA. He has the highest assist to turnover ratio out of everyone with more than 10 games played at 5.4.


Code
library(hoopR)
library(tidyverse)
library(tidyr)
library(zoo)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)
library(ggalt)
nba <- read_csv("nbaadvanced.csv")
totals <- read_csv("nbatotals.csv")
pergame <- read_csv("nbapergame.csv")
tov <- read_csv("nbaplaybyplay.csv")
lineups <-  nba_leaguedashlineups(league_id = '00', season = year_to_season(most_recent_nba_season() - 1))
per36 <- read_csv("nbaper36.csv")
allstar <- read_csv("Preandpostallstar.csv")

AstTov <- pergame |> inner_join(nba, by=c("Player")) |> select(Player, GS.x, G.x, MP.x, AST, TOV, `AST%`, `TOV%`, `USG%`, OWS, WS, WS/48) |> 
  group_by(Player) |> rename(G = G.x, MP=MP.x, GS=GS.x) |> 
  filter(MP >=10, `USG%`>=10) |> 
  mutate(AstTovRatio =AST/TOV )

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data= AstTov, aes( x=TOV, y=AST, size=`USG%`, color= `USG%`), alpha = .3) + 
  scale_size(range = c(1, 10), name="USG%") +
  geom_smooth(data=AstTov, aes(x=TOV, y=AST), method="lm", se=FALSE, color="lightgrey") +
  geom_text_repel(data=AstTov, aes(x=TOV, y=AST, label= Player)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Most effective passers in the NBA",
    subtitle ="Tyrese Haliburton is one of the top passers in the NBA with less turnovers on lower usage.",
    caption ="Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss"
  ) + theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"), axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), plot.title.position = "plot")









Haliburton is third in assists per game having at least 8% less usage and one and a half less minutes per game than the top six players in assists. He also averages at least 1.5 less turnovers than those six players. He is the greatest decision maker with the ball in his hands. What kind of mistakes do the best passers make in the NBA?


Code
types <- tov |> inner_join(totals, by=c("Player", "MP")) |>
  rename(Age= Age.x, Team=Team.x, Pos= Pos.x, G=G.x, GS=GS.x, TurnoverByPass=BadPass, TurnoverByDribble=LostBall) |>     select(Player, Age, Team, Pos, G, GS, MP, OnCourt, `On-Off`, TurnoverByPass, TurnoverByDribble, AST, `eFG%`, PGA )

toppassers <- types |> filter(AST >= 400) |> arrange(desc(AST)) |> 
  pivot_longer(
    cols=starts_with("TurnoverBy"), 
    names_to="Type", 
    values_to="Turnover") 

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = toppassers, aes(x=reorder(Player, AST), weight = Turnover, fill = Type)) + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("yellow","blue")) +
  coord_flip() + theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "The top passers make a lot of mistakes with the ball", 
    subtitle = "The two main types of turnovers committed by players with more than 400 assists.",
    caption = "Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss",
    x= "Most Total Assisst",
    y="Turnovers" )+ 
  theme(plot.title.position = "plot",  
        plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"), 
        axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12))









There are two main types of mistakes players make with the ball. The ball gets stolen when in the player’s possession or when passing to another player. Haliburton has the second lowest number of these mistakes out of the top players in assists. The player lower? Tyus Jones who has 222 less assists than him. Haliburton rarely makes dangerous passes or uses excessive dribbles. His decisions translate to less careless play by the Pacers.


Code
lineup <-   lineups[["Lineups"]] |> mutate_at(6:34, as.numeric) 
withHali <- lineup |> 
  filter(grepl("Haliburton", GROUP_NAME)) |> 
  group_by(TEAM_ABBREVIATION) |>
  summarise(TotalAssists = sum(AST),
           TotalTurnovers = sum(TOV), 
           TotalFGM = sum(FGM),
           TotalFGA = sum(FGA)) |>
  mutate(AstTovRatio= TotalAssists/TotalTurnovers,
         AvgFGpct = TotalFGM/TotalFGA)

withoutHali <- lineup |>
  filter(TEAM_ABBREVIATION == "IND", grepl("Haliburton", GROUP_NAME)== FALSE) |> 
  group_by(TEAM_ABBREVIATION) |>
  summarise(TotalAssists = sum(AST),
            TotalTurnovers = sum(TOV), 
           TotalFGM = sum(FGM),
           TotalFGA = sum(FGA)) |>
  mutate(AstTovRatio= TotalAssists/TotalTurnovers,
         AvgFGpct = TotalFGM/TotalFGA)

TeamTovRatio <- lineup |> 
  group_by(TEAM_ABBREVIATION) |>
summarise(TotalAssists = sum(AST),
            TotalTurnovers = sum(TOV), 
           TotalFGM = sum(FGM),
           TotalFGA = sum(FGA)) |>
  mutate(AstTovRatio= TotalAssists/TotalTurnovers,
         AvgFGpct = TotalFGM/TotalFGA)
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=TeamTovRatio, aes(x=reorder(TEAM_ABBREVIATION, AstTovRatio), weight= AstTovRatio), fill= "lightgrey") +  
  geom_bar(data=withHali, aes(x=reorder(TEAM_ABBREVIATION, AstTovRatio), weight= AstTovRatio), fill="yellow") + 
  geom_bar(data=withoutHali, aes(x=reorder(TEAM_ABBREVIATION, AstTovRatio), weight= AstTovRatio), fill ="blue") + 
  coord_flip() + theme_minimal() + 
  labs(x ="", y = "Assist/Turnover Ratio",
    title = "Pacers with Haliburton are the best passing team",
    subtitle ="<span style = 'color:blue;'>Without Haliburton,</span> the Pacers are 10th in Assist/Turnover Ratio. <span style = 'color:yellow;'>With Haliburton,</span> they are 1st.",
    caption ="Source: Hoopr | By Evan Preuss" ) +  
  theme(
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(), 
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"), plot.title.position = "plot", 
    axis.title = element_text(size = 9)
  )









Haliburton is not only the most efficient passer in the NBA but also makes his team the most efficient distributing team in the NBA. The Indiana Pacers have the best assist to turnover ratio at 2.47. With Haliburton in the lineup the assist to turnover ratio is 2.64; without him it is 2.09. Time to get a little more advanced.


Code
nbaast <- nba |> filter(is.na(`AST%`) == FALSE, is.na(`TOV%`) == FALSE) |>
  filter(MP >=1000)
topastpct <- nbaast |> filter(`AST%`>=33.3)

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data= nbaast, aes(x=`TOV%`, y=`AST%`)) +
  geom_point(data= topastpct, aes(x=`TOV%`, y=`AST%`), color="blue") +
  geom_text_repel(data=topastpct, aes(x=`TOV%`, y=`AST%`, label= Player)) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Advanced stats show Haliburton is the best passer", 
    subtitle = "<span style = 'color:blue;'>Players with 1/3 of the teams assists</span> while playing usually have a high turnover percentage...",
    caption = "Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss",
    x= "Turnover %",
    y="Assist %",
  )+  theme(plot.title.position = "plot",  
            plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple())









Assist % tells you what percent of the team’s assists are from the player when in the game. Out of all players with a third of the team’s assists when on the court, Haliburton has the least turnovers in 100 possessions. Advanced metrics seem to also favor Haliburton. However, many NPCs have argued that he is too inconsistent and gets worse as the season continues.


Code
splits <- allstar |> 
  mutate(TOperGame = TOV/G, AstTovRatio =`AST/G`/TOperGame)    |> select(Player, Value, AstTovRatio) |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = Value, values_from = AstTovRatio)

ggplot() +
  geom_dumbbell(data =splits, aes(y=Player, x=Pre, xend= Post),
    size = 2,
    color = "grey",
    colour_x = "yellow",
    colour_xend = "blue") + theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x="Assist to Turnover Ratio", 
    y="",
    title="Player's passing efficiency splits during the season", 
    subtitle="The best passers assist to turnover ratio <span style = 'color:yellow;'>before</span> and <span style = 'color:blue;'>after</span> the allstar break is not close.",
    caption="Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss"
    ) +  theme(plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 9), 
    plot.subtitle= element_textbox_simple(), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    ) 









Haliburton started this season with the same hamstring injury that affected him at the end of last season. Now he is fully healthy and playing better than ever. After the all-star break, Haliburton is showcasing historic numbers with a 9.25 assist to turnover ratio. He is currently on pace to have the third highest assist to turnover ratio ever in a season while averaging 9.2 assists per game.

title: Impressive Sports Statistics

The 1980s Denver Nuggets were an anomaly in the NBA.

title: The 1980s Denver Nuggets were an anomaly in the NBA.
text:
What most people today remember from 1980s NBA basketball if at all was the dominance of the Celtics and Lakers during those years. It fueled a rivalry between Magic Johnson and Larry Bird with the rise of upcoming stars. What you might not remember was the Denver Nuggets putting up historic numbers.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)
library(ggalt)
library(gt)

teamstats <- read_csv("1980snba.csv")
oppstats <- read_csv("opposingstats.csv")
advstats <- read_csv("1980advanced.csv")
pace <- read_csv("nbapace.csv")

eighties <- teamstats |> inner_join(advstats, by=c("Season", "Team" )) |> 
  select(Season, Team, FG, FGA, `FG%`, `3P`, `3PA`, `3P%`, `2P`, `2PA`, `2P%`, FT, FTA, `FT%`, AST, TOV, PTS, W, L, ORtg, DRtg, NRtg, Pace, `TOV%`, `DefeFG%`) |>   
  mutate(Team =
         case_when(
            Team == "Kansas City Kings" ~ "Sacramento Kings",
            Team == "San Diego Clippers" ~ "Los Angeles Clippers",
                 TRUE ~ Team )) |>
    mutate(AstTovRatio = AST/TOV) 

nuggets <- eighties |> filter(Team == "Denver Nuggets")

decadeavgs <- eighties |> group_by(Team) |> summarize(avgPTS = mean(PTS),
      avgFG = mean(FG),
      avgFGA = mean(FGA),
     `avgFG%` = mean(`FG%`),
      avg3P = mean(`3P`),
      avg3PA = mean(`3PA`),
     `avg3P%` = mean(`3P%`),
      avg2P = mean(`2P`),
     avg2PA = mean(`2PA`),
     `avg2P%` = mean(`2P%`),
     avgFT = mean(FT),
     avgFTA = mean(FTA),
     `avgFT%` = mean(`FT%`),
     avgAST = mean(AST),
     avgTOV = mean(TOV),
     avgW = mean(W),
     avgL = mean(L),
     avgORtg= mean(ORtg),
     avgDRtg = mean(DRtg),
     avgPace = mean(Pace),
     `avgTOV%` = mean(`TOV%`),
     `avgDefFg%` = mean(`DefeFG%`)) |>
  mutate(AstTovRatio = avgAST/avgTOV) 

oppavgs <- oppstats |> mutate(Team =
         case_when(
            Team == "Kansas City Kings" ~ "Sacramento Kings",
            Team == "San Diego Clippers" ~ "Los Angeles Clippers",
                 TRUE ~ Team )) |>
  group_by(Team) |> summarize(oppavgPTS = mean(PTS),
      oppavgFG = mean(FG),
      oppavgFGA = mean(FGA),
     `oppavgFG%` = mean(`FG%`),
      oppavg3P = mean(`3P`),
      oppavg3PA = mean(`3PA`),
     `oppavg3P%` = mean(`3P%`),
      oppavg2P = mean(`2P`),
     oppavg2PA = mean(`2PA`),
     `oppavg2P%` = mean(`2P%`),
     oppavgFT = mean(FT),
     oppavgFTA = mean(FTA),
     `oppavgFT%` = mean(`FT%`),
     oppavgAST = mean(AST),
     oppavgTOV = mean(TOV)) |>
  mutate(AstTovRatio = oppavgAST/oppavgTOV) |>
inner_join(decadeavgs, by=c("Team" ))

filterpace <- pace |> filter(SEASON == "1980-81" | SEASON == "1981-82" | SEASON == "1982-83" | SEASON == "1983-84" | SEASON == "1984-85" | SEASON == "1985-86" | SEASON == "1986-87" | SEASON == "1987-88" | SEASON == "1988-89" | SEASON == "1989-90"
) |>
  rename(Season=SEASON, TotalPoints=PTS, PTS=PPG) 

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=eighties, aes(x=Season, y=PTS, group=Team), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=nuggets, aes(x=Season, y=PTS, group=1), color="navy") +
  geom_line(data=filterpace, aes(x=Season, y=PTS, group=1), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x="1982-83", y=127, label= "Highest scoring season ever"),  color="navy") +
   geom_text(aes(x="1981-82", y=122, label="Denver Nuggets"), color="navy") +
 theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "The Denver Nuggets put up record scoring numbers",
    subtitle ="During the 1980s, the Devner Nuggets were consistently the higest scoring team in the NBA.",
    caption ="Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss"
  ) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"), axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), plot.title.position = "plot") 









During the 1980s, the Nuggets were coached by Doug Moe who implemented a different style of basketball called “Run & Gun”. Their second season under coach Moe the Nuggets scored 126.5 points per game setting a NBA record for most points per game. They were also consistently one of the highest scoring teams throughout the 80s having five of the six seasons with over 120 points per game.


Code
ggplot() +
 geom_point(data= eighties, aes(x=Pace, y=AstTovRatio)) +
  geom_point(data= nuggets, aes(x=Pace, y=AstTovRatio), color="blue") + 
  geom_hline(yintercept=1.461003, color="dark grey") +
  geom_vline(xintercept=101.0288    , color="dark grey") +
  geom_text(aes(x=109, y=1.75, label="Push the Pace, Good Passing"), color="navy") +
  geom_text(aes(x=95, y=1.2, label="Slow Pace, Bad Passing"), color="red") +
  annotate("rect", fill = "blue", alpha = 0.1, 
        xmin = 105, xmax = Inf,
        ymin = 1.60, ymax = Inf) +
  
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "No one was better at effectively pushing the pace", 
    subtitle = "<span style = 'color:blue;'>The Denver Nuggets</span> played faster and took care of the ball better than any team in the 1980s.",
    caption = "Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss",
    x= "Pace",
    y="Assist to Turnover Ratio") + 
  theme(plot.title.position = "plot",  
        plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),          axis.title = element_text(size = 9), 
        plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple())









The Nuggets run & gun offense relied on the team pushing the pace and quickly passing the ball. The goal is to not have the ball in a player’s hands for more than two seconds. The Nuggets did this very effectively and pushed pace more than any team while also taking care of the ball very well. No team in the 1980s compared to the Nuggets’ speed and efficiency with the ball.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=oppavgs, 
    aes(y=reorder(Team, avgPTS), x=oppavgPTS, xend=avgPTS),
    size=1.5,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "red",
    colour_xend = "green") +
theme_minimal() + 
  labs(
    title = "Nuggets scoring margins were a bit above average", 
    subtitle = "Showing a <span style = 'color:green;'>team average points</span> and <span style = 'color:red;'>opponent average points</span> over the decade.",
    caption = "Source: Basketball Reference | By Evan Preuss",
    x= "Average Points per Game",
    y="",)+  
  theme(plot.title.position = "plot",  
            plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple())









Scoring wise the Nuggets were in a league of their own but their biggest issue was defense. The Nuggets gave up a staggering 118.6 points per game which was the second worst in the NBA after the Orlando Magic. However, the Magic were only in the NBA since 1989 so stats for their team is only one year. The closest team to opponent points per game that played throughout the 80s were the Warriors who allowed five less points on average.


Code
tableavgs <- oppavgs |> 
  filter(grepl("Magic", Team) == FALSE,
         grepl("Hornets", Team) == FALSE,
         grepl("Timberwolves", Team) == FALSE,
         grepl("Heat", Team) == FALSE) |>
mutate(WinPercent = avgW/82) |>
  select(Team, avgPTS, oppavgPTS,  `avgFG%`, `oppavgFG%`, WinPercent) |>
  arrange(desc(WinPercent)) |> top_n(10)


Selecting by WinPercent


Code
tableavgs |> gt() |>  
  cols_label(
    WinPercent = "Win Percent",
    avgPTS = "PPG",
    oppavgPTS = "Opponent PPG", 
    `avgFG%` = "FG%",
    `oppavgFG%` = "Opponent FG%") |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Nuggets lack of defense made the offense ineffective",
    subtitle = "Inspite of the 1980s Denver Nuggets having record high scoring they could never win it all with their incompetence on defense.") |> 
   tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Evan Preuss  |  **Source:** [Sports Reference]")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")) |> 
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)))  |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  fmt_percent(
    columns = c(WinPercent,`avgFG%`,`oppavgFG%`),
    decimals = 1) |>
    tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "blue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Denver Nuggets"))








Nuggets lack of defense made the offense ineffective


Inspite of the 1980s Denver Nuggets having record high scoring they could never win it all with their incompetence on defense.

By: Evan Preuss | Source: [Sports Reference]








Due to the lack of defense, the Nuggets got farther than the Western Conference Finals in this time. They were 7th in win percentage during this time at with 54% and were the only team in the top 10 allowing over 50% shooting from the field. The 1980s Nuggets show that pace can only get a team so far without a good defense.
